contents.description:
HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language. It is the core structure of any webpage and defines the layout using elements like headings, paragraphs, images, lists, and forms. HTML provides the skeleton, CSS adds styling, and JavaScript adds interactivity.


Here’s a simple HTML example:


<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8" />
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" />
    <title>Simple HTML Page</title>
</head>
<body>
    <h1>Welcome to My Page</h1>
    <p>This is a basic example of an HTML structure.</p>

    <a href="https://example.com">Visit Example</a>

    <ul>
        <li>HTML</li>
        <li>CSS</li>
        <li>JavaScript</li>
    </ul>
</body>
</html>

DOCTYPE is required to tell the browser which HTML standard to use. It forces the browser into standards mode, ensuring consistent and correct rendering. Without it, the browser may fall back to quirks mode, causing layout and CSS issues.

Block elements take up the full width and start on a new line, like <div> and <p>.


Inline elements only take as much space as needed, don’t start a new line, like <span> and <a>.


Inline-block elements combine both: they stay inline but allow width and height to be set, useful for horizontally aligned boxes.
contents.text: What is the difference between inline, block, and inline-block elements?

contents.description:
Semantic HTML tags are elements that clearly describe their meaning and structure. They help browsers, developers, and search engines understand the content. Examples include <header>, <footer>, <article>, <section>, <nav>, and <aside>.

Using semantic tags improves accessibility, SEO, and code readability compared to non-semantic tags like <div> and <span>.


Examples: <header>, <footer>, <article>, <section>, <nav>.
contents.text: What are semantic HTML tags? Can you give examples?

contents.description: SEO stands for Search Engine Optimization. It is the practice of improving a website’s visibility in search engine results to attract more organic traffic. It involves optimizing content, meta tags, semantic HTML, page speed, and backlinks. In Angular, we can improve SEO using Angular Universal, semantic tags, and dynamic meta tags.
A Web Component is a set of web platform features that allows you to create reusable, encapsulated, and custom HTML elements that work across modern browsers.

The id attribute uniquely identifies a single element on a page, while class can be used for multiple elements. id is commonly used for unique components like a header or footer, whereas class is used to group elements for styling or scripting. In CSS, id is selected with # and class with .. In JavaScript, id can be accessed with getElementById and class with getElementsByClassName or querySelectorAll.

data-* attributes in HTML are custom attributes that allow storing extra information on elements. They are accessible via JavaScript using the dataset property. In Angular, they are useful for passing extra information to event handlers or storing element-specific metadata without adding extra component state. For example, you can store a user ID on a button with data-user-id and retrieve it in the click event.


// In JavaScript 


<div data-user-id="101" data-role="admin">John Doe</div>

const div = document.querySelector('div');
console.log(div.dataset.userId);  // 101
console.log(div.dataset.role);    // admin

// In Angular


<button (click)="handleClick($event)" data-user-id="101">Click Me</button>

handleClick(event: Event) {
  const target = event.target as HTMLElement;
  console.log(target.dataset.userId); // 101
}
contents.text: What are data- attributes* in HTML? How are they useful in Angular?

contents.description:
<div> is a block-level element that starts on a new line and is used to group larger sections or layouts.<span> is an inline element used to group small portions of text or inline elements for styling.


<div> can have width and height, while <span> cannot. Use <div> for structure and <span> for inline styling.

Both localStorage and sessionStorage are Web Storage APIs that allow browsers to store key-value data on the client side.


localStorage and sessionStorage are client-side storage APIs.

localStorage stores data persistently across browser sessions, while sessionStorage stores data only for the current tab session.


Both store data as key-value strings and are commonly used in Angular for storing tokens, user preferences, or temporary form data.

Placing <script> in the <head> loads and executes the JavaScript before the HTML is rendered, which can block page rendering and may not have access to DOM elements defined later.

Placing <script> at the end of <body> ensures the script runs after the DOM is parsed, allowing safe DOM access and better performance.


In modern practice, using <script defer> in the head is also common.


The best approach is to either place <script> at the end of <body> or use <script defer> in the <head>. Both ensure scripts run after the DOM is parsed, preventing render-blocking issues and allowing safe DOM access. async is only for independent scripts that don’t rely on the DOM.

The <meta> tag provides metadata about the HTML document, which is not displayed on the page but used by browsers, search engines, and services.

Common purposes include setting character encoding, viewport for responsive design, page description and keywords for SEO, author info, and controlling browser behavior like refresh or redirects.


// Character Encoding

<meta charset="UTF-8">


// Responsive Design

<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">


//  SEO (Description & Keywords)

<meta name="description" content="This is a sample website for Angular tutorials.">
<meta name="keywords" content="Angular, HTML, CSS, JavaScript">


// Author

<meta name="author" content="Vivek Maurya">


// Page Refresh / Redirect

<meta http-equiv="refresh" content="5;url=https://example.com">
contents.text: What is the purpose of the <meta> tag?

contents.description:
The viewport meta tag tells the browser how to render a webpage on different devices.

It is essential for responsive design, allowing the page to scale correctly on mobile devices. For example, <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0"> sets the page width to the device width and the initial zoom to 1, ensuring a proper mobile layout.


<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
  <title>Responsive Page</title>
</head>
<body>
  <div class="container">Content here</div>
</body>

The <link> tag is used to attach external resources like CSS, fonts, or icons to the HTML document and is placed in the <head>. It is not visible or clickable.


The <a> tag creates a clickable hyperlink in the page content that navigates users to another URL. <link> is for resources; <a> is for navigation.


// <link> Tag (External CSS)

<head>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css">
</head>


// <a> Tag (Hyperlink)

<body>
  <a href="https://example.com" target="_blank">Visit Example</a>
</body>

<input type="text"> is used for single-line text such as name or email, while <textarea> is used for multi-line text like comments or messages. The input tag is self-closing and supports only one line, whereas <textarea> allows multiple lines and is better for larger text entry.


// Input (Single-line)

<input type="text" placeholder="Enter your name">


// extarea (Multi-line)

<textarea rows="4" cols="40" placeholder="Enter your message"></textarea>
contents.text: What is the difference between <input type="text"> and <textarea>?

contents.description: The <button> element is more flexible because it can contain HTML elements like icons or spans, and its default type in a form is submit. <input type="button"> is a self-closing tag that can only display text through the value attribute and never submits a form. Because of flexibility and styling options, <button> is preferred in modern applications.

GET sends form data through the URL, which makes it visible, limited in size, and suitable for retrieving or searching data. POST sends data in the request body, which is more secure, supports large amounts of data, and is used for actions like login, registration, or submitting sensitive information.


// GET example

<form method="GET" action="/search">
  <input type="text" name="query">
  <button type="submit">Search</button>
</form>

Resulting URL:
 /search?query=angular


// POST example

<form method="POST" action="/login">
  <input type="text" name="username">
  <input type="password" name="password">
  <button type="submit">Login</button>
</form>

Data is sent in the request body, not visible in URL.

HTML is the older standard for structuring web pages, but it had limitations like no native multimedia or storage support. HTML5 is a modern upgrade that introduces semantic tags, built-in audio/video support, canvas for graphics, new form input types, and APIs like localStorage, geolocation, and web workers. It makes websites more interactive, mobile-friendly, and capable of complex applications without relying on external plugins.

srcset lets the browser choose the best image from a list of multiple resolutions.

It improves performance and responsiveness by loading the most appropriate image based on screen size and pixel density.


<img
  src="image-small.jpg"
  srcset="
    image-small.jpg 300w,
    image-medium.jpg 600w,
    image-large.jpg 1200w
  "
  sizes="(max-width: 600px) 300px, (max-width: 900px) 600px, 1200px"
  alt="Sample Image"
/>
src loads and embeds content into the document (like images, scripts), while href links to external resources (like CSS files, webpages) without embedding them.
The src (source) attribute tells the browser where to load and embed external resources. such as <img>, <script>, <iframe>, <audio>, <video>, <source>, and <embed>.

HTML5 Canvas is a special HTML element (<canvas>) that allows you to draw graphics, such as shapes, text, animations, and charts, using JavaScript.


It provides a pixel-based drawing area inside the browser.

Everything drawn on a canvas is dynamic and controlled by JavaScript.


<canvas id="myCanvas" width="200" height="100"></canvas>

<script>
  const canvas = document.getElementById('myCanvas');
  const ctx = canvas.getContext('2d');

  ctx.fillStyle = 'blue';
  ctx.fillRect(20, 20, 150, 60);
</script>

SVG (Scalable Vector Graphics) is an XML-based format used for creating vector graphics in the browser.


Unlike images like PNG or JPG, SVG does not lose quality even when zoomed or resized.

SVG graphics are mathematically drawn, not pixel-based, which makes them sharp and scalable on any device.

data-* attributes allow storing custom data on HTML elements that can be accessed via JavaScript or frameworks like Angular, making it easier to handle dynamic behaviors without adding extra DOM elements.


// Example with Angular Event Handling

<button (click)="deleteUser($event)" data-user-id="55">
  Delete
</button>

deleteUser(event: Event) {
  const element = event.target as HTMLElement;
  const id = element.dataset['userId'];
  console.log('Deleting user with id:', id);
}


// Reading data-* inside a Custom Directive

<div data-color="red" appHighlight>
  Highlight me
</div>

@Directive({
  selector: '[appHighlight]'
})
export class HighlightDirective {
  constructor(private el: ElementRef) {}

  ngOnInit() {
    const color = this.el.nativeElement.dataset['color'];
    this.el.nativeElement.style.backgroundColor = color;
  }
}


// Passing dynamic Angular values to data- attributes*:

<div [attr.data-role]="user.role" [attr.data-id]="user.id">
  {{ user.name }}
</div>

Custom data attributes (data-*) are used to store extra information (metadata) directly in HTML elements without affecting the UI or layout. This data can be easily accessed using JavaScript or frameworks like Angular, and is often used to add behavior, configuration, or identifiers to DOM elements.

Accessibility (A11Y) means building websites that everyone—including people with disabilities—can navigate, understand, and interact with easily.


In Angular, we achieve accessibility by using semantic HTML, ARIA attributes, keyboard navigation, proper focus management, accessible Angular Material components, and WCAG-compliant color contrast and labels.

ARIA is a set of HTML attributes that improve accessibility by helping assistive technologies understand the role, state, and behavior of UI elements—especially dynamic components in frameworks like Angular.
<b> and <i> are purely presentational (bold/italic), while <strong> and <em> are semantic tags that add meaning and help with accessibility and SEO.
contents.text: What is the difference between <b> vs <strong> and <i> vs <em>?

contents.description: rel="noopener noreferrer" is used with target="_blank" links to prevent security risks (like tab-napping) and protect user privacy by blocking access to window.opener and hiding the referrer.

Self-closing tags are HTML elements that don’t wrap any content and therefore don’t need a closing tag.

Tags like <img>, <br>, <hr>, <input>, and <meta> are self-closing because they represent standalone elements.

In HTML5, using the trailing slash (/>) is optional, but the tag still behaves as self-closing.

HTML5 supports offline storage through localStorage, sessionStorage, IndexedDB, and modern Service Workers with Cache API, enabling web apps to store data locally and work without an internet connection.
